## Readings by Course Theme

### BELIEF: Why People Believe Weird Things

These readings explore the psychology of belief formation, pseudoscience, and why intelligent people sometimes hold irrational beliefs.

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Key Readings

**Shermer, M.** (2002). *Why people believe weird things: Pseudoscience, superstition, and other confusions of our time.* St. Martin's Griffin.

- The foundational text on this topic. Shermer examines everything from alien abductions to Holocaust denial.

**Shermer, M.** (2002). Smart people believe weird things. *Scientific American, 287*(3), 35. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1038/scientificamerican0902-35){target="_blank"}

- Why does education not protect against irrational beliefs? Shermer argues smart people are better at rationalizing beliefs they arrived at for non-rational reasons.

**Matthews, R.** (2005). Why do people believe weird things? *Significance, 2*(4), 182-184. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1740-9713.2005.00134.x){target="_blank"}

- A statistician's perspective on why "irrational" beliefs may be more rational than scientists assume.

**Boudry, M., Blancke, S., & Pigliucci, M.** (2015). What makes weird beliefs thrive? The epidemiology of pseudoscience. *Philosophical Psychology, 28*(8), 1177-1198. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1080/09515089.2014.971946){target="_blank"}

- How do pseudoscientific beliefs spread? An epidemiological model of belief transmission.

**Boudry, M., & Braeckman, J.** (2012). How convenient! The epistemic rationale of self-validating belief systems. *Philosophical Psychology, 25*(3), 341-364. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1080/09515089.2011.579420){target="_blank"}

- Why are some belief systems so resistant to contrary evidence? The psychology of "immunizing strategies."
:::

### EMOTION: Regulation and Expression

Understanding how we manage our emotional responses is central to many of the psychological phenomena depicted in our films.

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Key Readings

**Gross, J. J.** (2015). Emotion regulation: Current status and future prospects. *Psychological Inquiry, 26*(1), 1-26. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1080/1047840X.2014.940781){target="_blank"}

- The definitive overview of emotion regulation research. Gross introduces the process model that distinguishes between different regulation strategies (suppression vs. reappraisal).
:::

---

### MOTIVATION: Social Dominance and Power

What drives people to seek power over others? How do social hierarchies shape behavior?

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Key Readings

**Pratto, F., Sidanius, J., Stallworth, L. M., & Malle, B. F.** (1994). Social dominance orientation: A personality variable predicting social and political attitudes. *Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 67*(4), 741-763. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.67.4.741){target="_blank"}

- Introduces Social Dominance Orientation (SDO)—the preference for social hierarchy. SDO predicts attitudes toward policies affecting intergroup relations.
:::

---

### UNCERTAINTY: Deception and Detection

Can we really tell when someone is lying? These readings challenge common assumptions about deception detection.

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Key Readings

**Vrij, A., Hartwig, M., & Granhag, P. A.** (2019). Reading lies: Nonverbal communication and deception. *Annual Review of Psychology, 70*, 295-317. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-psych-010418-103135){target="_blank"}

- A comprehensive review showing that nonverbal cues to deception are "faint and unreliable" and that people are mediocre lie detectors. Challenges the popular belief in body language as a lie detection tool.
:::

---

### MURDER: Psychopathy, Morality, and Criminal Responsibility

These readings explore the intersection of psychology and law, particularly regarding moral reasoning and criminal responsibility.

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Key Readings

**Marshall, J., Watts, A. L., & Lilienfeld, S. O.** (2018). Do psychopathic individuals possess a misaligned moral compass? A meta-analytic examination of psychopathy's relations with moral judgment. *Personality Disorders: Theory, Research, and Treatment, 9*(1), 40-50. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1037/per0000226){target="_blank"}

- Meta-analysis challenging the assumption that psychopaths lack moral understanding. The relationship between psychopathy and moral judgment is smaller than commonly believed.

**The "Guilty Mind:" Mens Rea** (Book Section)

- Foundational reading on *mens rea* (the "guilty mind")—the mental state requirement for criminal liability. Essential for understanding how psychology intersects with legal determinations of criminal intent.

**Diamond, B. L.** (1961). Criminal responsibility of the mentally ill. *Stanford Law Review, 14*(1), 59-86. [Read](https://heinonline.org/HOL/P?h=hein.journals/stflr14&i=79){target="_blank"}

- Classic article on the insanity defense and the legal-psychological complexities of holding mentally ill individuals criminally responsible.

**Diamantis, M. E.** (2015). Corporate criminal minds. *Notre Dame Law Review, 91*(5), 2049-2090. [Read](https://heinonline.org/HOL/P?h=hein.journals/tndl91&i=2099){target="_blank"}

- Can corporations have criminal intent? An exploration of how we attribute mental states to non-human entities.
:::

## How to Use These Resources

### For Class Discussions
Before we discuss a film, consider skimming the relevant readings. They provide theoretical frameworks for understanding character motivations, psychological phenomena, and the realism (or lack thereof) in film portrayals.

### For Your Own Learning
These readings go deeper than our class discussions can. If a topic sparks your interest, dive into the primary sources.

### Citation
All references are available in proper citation format through the Zotero library. Export in APA, MLA, or any format you need.
